history.content: EE 16a has never been offered over summer before so i'm afraid no one will be able to share personal experiences from that.

children.subject: I gave a big long description for 61BL in @3407, feel free to ask any other questions!

history.content:
General info:

-you need to be quick to pick up material, but the upside is that there is very little time to forget it. There were 2 midterms and a final squeezed into 8 weeks, and its hard to forget when there's a big exam every 2-3 weeks.

-FIND A GOOD LAB PARTNER EARLY. 61BL (summer version of 61B) is a lab class. You really really want a lab partner who you can stick with through the semester and rely on to get code out EVERY DAY. 

-The labs were due 23 hours after you began them, so you have to be with the course at all times. You can't just put it off to study for another class, since you have to devote time every day.  

I really enjoyed cs61BL. I felt I learned a lot better by actually coding than listening to someone lecture about coding.

I wouldn't recommend trying to take another tech (read:homework intensive) class with it though. I took Physics 7C and 61BL summer 2016 and had very little free time. The labs generally took 3~ hours on average, but some labs were much longer (meaning you had to do it on your own time within 23 hours) (p.s. streams lab LOL). 

from the course info page (which I found to be accurate):

"
What sort of time commitment should I expect?
A lot. This is a summer course, which means it is run at twice the speed of a normal course. In addition, 61B naturally has more involved programming than 61A, and 61BL has even more. We strongly recommend not taking any other courses alongside 61BL.
We cannot predict how many hours you will spend on the course; some students take more time than others. However, we can at least give you a brief breakdown of what you will have to do in this course:
  • Students will spend 12 hours a week in lab.
  • Expect to take time after labs to complete the lab.
  • There is a single two-hour lecture each week.
  • There are three projects in the 8 weeks of the course.
  • There are three exams in the 8 weeks of the course.

"

That said, it is certainly possible, you just might not enjoy your summer much!

children.subject: If a student took Math 54 already, is it still advised against to take EE16A and CS61BL during the summer?
EE16A summer edition will be folding 2 weeks of Fall/Spring semester work into a week, so we do not recommend taking another class with big time commitment.

history.content: Can anyone share their experiences taking one or both of these classes during the summer? Maybe general advice or tips for CS summer classes in general?
history.subject: EE16A and CS61B (Summer)
